Trial_Design.evidence: patients following surgery with pain intensity of greater than 4 on an 11-point numerical rating scale were randomized

Participants.evidence: At 13 hospital sites in the United States, patients following surgery with pain intensity of greater than 4 on an 11-point numerical rating scale

Intervention.evidence: randomized to receive SSTS dispensing a 15-μg sufentanil tablet sublingually with a 20-minute lockout or an identical system dispensing a placebo tablet sublingually

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy and safety of a sufentanil sublingual tablet system (SSTS) for the management of postoperative pain following open abdominal surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary end point was time-weighted summed pain intensity difference (SPID) over 48 hours.

Blinding.evidence: an identical system dispensing a placebo tablet sublingually

Result_Outcome.evidence: Summed pain intensity difference over 48 hours was significantly higher in the SSTS group than in the placebo group (least squares mean [SEM], 105.60 [10.14] vs 55.58 [13.11]; P = 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Safety parameters, including adverse events and vital signs, were similar for SSTS and placebo.
